question:
The first ruler to accept the Subsidiary Treaty was-

I.A.S. (Pre) 1994
solution:
The first ruler to accept a well-framed Subsidiary Treaty was the Nizam of Hyderabad in 1798. This move marked a significant turning point, as Lord Wellesley's Subsidiary Alliance aimed to bring Indian princely states under British influence.

The Nizam agreed to station British troops in his territory and, in return, gave up control over his external affairs. This treaty made Hyderabad the first major princely state to formally surrender certain sovereign powers.

Other rulers joined later: the Nawab of Awadh accepted in 1801 under pressure, Peshwa Bajirao II in 1802 following his defeat in the Second Anglo-Maratha War, and the King of Travancore also signed on, but not before the Nizam. So, while many eventually signed, Hyderabad led the way.

question:
During whose period was the Subsidiary Treaty implemented?

U.P.P.C.S (Mains) 2011
solution:
• The Subsidiary Alliance System was implemented during the tenure of Lord Wellesley, who served as the Governor-General of India from 1798 to 1805.
  • It was a strategic diplomatic policy aimed at establishing British dominance in India without direct annexation.
  • Key features of the policy:
    • Indian rulers had to maintain British troops in their territory at their own expense.
    • They were forbidden from forming alliances with other powers without British approval.
    • A British Resident was placed at their courts.
  • Through this system, Wellesley secured control over major princely states like Hyderabad, Awadh, Mysore, and the Marathas.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Cornwallis preceded Wellesley and focused more on judicial and administrative reforms.
  • Sir John Shore followed Cornwallis and maintained a policy of non-intervention.
  • Lord Auckland came much later and is known for initiating the First Anglo-Afghan War (1839).

question:
Who was the first Indian native ruler to accept the Subsidiary Treaty System?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2013
option_3: Dalip Singh of Punjab
solution:
• The first Indian native ruler to accept the Subsidiary Treaty System introduced by Lord Wellesley was the Nizam of Hyderabad.
  • In 1798, the Nizam Ali Khan of Hyderabad signed the subsidiary treaty with the British East India Company.
  • He agreed to:
    • Maintain a British subsidiary force within his territory.
    • Not enter into any alliance or war without British permission.
    • Allow the posting of a British Resident in his court.
  • This treaty was signed to seek British protection against the rising power of the Marathas and Mysore.

Additional Information:

  • Though Nawab of Awadh signed a similar treaty earlier, he was not considered fully independent at the time.
  • Scindia (Gwalior), Bhonsle (Nagpur), and Gaekwad (Baroda) accepted the subsidiary system later, mainly after military defeats.
  • Dalip Singh of Punjab became ruler much later and was never part of the subsidiary alliance system.

question:
Consider the following who entered into subsidiary alliance with Lord Wellesley and find out the correct chronology of the treaties made by them from the code given below:

(1) Hyderabad

(2) Mysore

(3) Awadh

(4) Scindia

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2014

Code :
solution:
To determine the correct chronological order of the Subsidiary Alliance treaties signed with Lord Wellesley, we analyze the historical timeline:

  1. Hyderabad – The first Indian ruler to sign a Subsidiary Treaty with Lord Wellesley in 1798.
  2. Mysore – After the defeat of Tipu Sultan in the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War (1799), the new Wodeyar ruler accepted the Subsidiary Alliance.
  3. Awadh – Nawab Saadat Ali Khan II signed the treaty in 1801, surrendering territory in lieu of maintaining British forces.
  4. Scindia (Gwalior) – Signed the treaty after the Second Anglo-Maratha War, in 1803.

Correct Chronological Order:

(1) Hyderabad → (2) Mysore → (3) Awadh → (4) Scindia

Correct Answer: (a) 1, 2, 3, 4

question:
Who introduced the Subsidiary Treaty System in administration to establish British supremacy over Indian states?

U.P.P.C.S (Mains) 2016
solution:
• Subsidiary Alliance System was a diplomatic strategy used by the British to establish control over Indian princely states without direct annexation.
  • It was introduced by Lord Wellesley in 1798 during his tenure as Governor-General of India (1798–1805).
  • Under this system, Indian rulers had to:
    • Accept British forces in their territory.
    • Pay for their maintenance or cede part of their territory.
    • Not form alliances with other powers without British approval.
  • In return, the British promised military protection.
  • Hyderabad was the first state to accept the alliance in 1798.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings focused on administrative and judicial reforms, not the Subsidiary Alliance.
  • Lord Cornwallis introduced the Permanent Settlement system.
  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse, not Subsidiary Alliance.

question:
The main objective of the East India Company in entering into a subsidiary treaty with the Rajput states was-

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 1992
option_1: To get military help against enemies
option_2: Protection of these states from Maratha-Pindari invasion
option_3: Receiving money in the form of Khiraj
option_4: Establishing the sovereignty of the British
solution:
• The main aim of the Subsidiary Alliance system, especially with Rajput and other Indian states, was to establish British supremacy without direct annexation.
  • By entering into subsidiary treaties, the British gained control over the foreign policy and defense of these states.
  • Although protection from Marathas and Pindaris was offered, it was merely a pretext — the real objective was political dominance.
  • The states lost their sovereignty and became dependent on the East India Company.

Additional Information:

  • The system was introduced by Lord Wellesley.
  • Rajput states like Jaipur, Jodhpur, and Udaipur entered into subsidiary treaties in the early 19th century.
  • These treaties weakened the autonomy of Indian rulers and increased British control.

question:
Which one of the following pairs is not correctly matched?

U.P. U.D.A./L.D.A. (Spl.) (Mains) 2010
option_1: Battle of Buxar - 1764
option_2: Subsidiary Treaty - 1863
option_3: Monopoly of East India Company in India - 1833
option_4: Opening of trade in India for British citizens and companies - 1813
solution:
• The Subsidiary Treaty system was introduced by Lord Wellesley in 1798, not in 1863. So, this pair is incorrectly matched.
  • Other options are correctly matched:
    • Battle of Buxar – 1764: Fought between British and the combined forces of Mir Qasim, Shuja-ud-Daula, and Shah Alam II.
    • Charter Act of 1833: Ended the monopoly of the East India Company in India, making it purely an administrative body.
    • Charter Act of 1813: Ended the trade monopoly, allowing British citizens and companies to trade in India (except tea and China trade).

Additional Information:

  • The Subsidiary Alliance started in 1798 with Hyderabad as the first state to accept it.
  • By 1803, many Indian states were under this system, including major Rajput states.

question:
At a time when empires in Europe were crumbling under the might of Napoleon, which one of the following Governor-Generals kept the British flag flying in India?

I.A.S. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The phrase "when empires in Europe were crumbling under Napoleon" refers to the period between 1799 and 1815, when Napoleon Bonaparte rose to power and dominated Europe.
  • During this exact period in India, Lord Wellesley served as the Governor-General (1798–1805).
  • Wellesley pursued an aggressive expansionist policy to strengthen British control, notably through:
    • The Subsidiary Alliance System
    • Victory in the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War (1799), defeating Tipu Sultan
    • Curtailing French influence in Indian princely states
  • His tenure ensured the British Empire remained strong and unshaken in India despite chaos in Europe caused by Napoleon.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie (1848–1856): Came much later, introduced the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Lord Cornwallis (1786–1793): Served before Napoleon's dominance.
  • Lord Hastings (1813–1823): Came after Napoleon’s peak influence had declined.

question:
The Anglo-Nepal war took place during the reign of-

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2010
solution:
• The Anglo-Nepal War (also known as the Gurkha War) took place between 1814 and 1816.
  • It was fought between the British East India Company and the Kingdom of Nepal.
  • The Governor-General of India at that time was Lord Hastings (tenure: 1813–1823).
  • The war ended with the Treaty of Sugauli (1816), through which Nepal ceded significant territory to the British.
  • The war was caused by territorial disputes and expansionist policies of both Nepal and the British.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Cornwallis served from 1786–1793 and briefly again in 1805.
  • Lord Wellesley was Governor-General from 1798–1805.
  • Warren Hastings served from 1773–1785.

question:
The treaty of Sugauli was signed in-

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Pre.) 2016
solution:
• The Treaty of Sugauli was signed between the British East India Company and the Kingdom of Nepal after the Anglo-Nepal War (1814–1816).
  • The treaty was signed in December 1815, though it came into effect in March 1816.
  • Under this treaty:
    • Nepal ceded large parts of its territory (including Sikkim, Kumaon, and Garhwal) to the British.
    • A British Resident was placed in Kathmandu.
  • It marked a significant British victory and reshaped the modern borders of Nepal.

Additional Information:

  • The war occurred during the tenure of Lord Hastings.
  • Sugauli (or Sugowlee) is in present-day East Champaran, Bihar.

question:
Which of the following pairs is not correctly matched?

U.P.U.D.A./L.D.A. (Mains) 2010

U.P.P.C.S (Pre) 2017
option_1: Hector Munro - Battle of Buxar
option_2: Lord Hastings - Anglo-Nepal War
option_3: Lord Wellesley - Fourth Anglo-Mysore War
option_4: Lord Cornwallis - Third Anglo-Maratha War
solution:
• (a) Hector Munro – Battle of Buxar: ✔ Correct
    • Fought in 1764, Hector Munro led the British forces against the combined armies of Mir Qasim, Shuja-ud-Daula, and Shah Alam II.
  • (b) Lord Hastings – Anglo-Nepal War: ✔ Correct
    • The Anglo-Nepal War (1814–1816) was fought under Lord Hastings' tenure as Governor-General.
  • (c) Lord Wellesley – Fourth Anglo-Mysore War: ✔ Correct
    • The Fourth Anglo-Mysore War (1799), which led to the death of Tipu Sultan, occurred during Wellesley’s tenure.
  • (d) Lord Cornwallis – Third Anglo-Maratha War: ✖ Incorrect
    • The Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818) happened during the time of Lord Hastings, not Lord Cornwallis.
    • Lord Cornwallis was associated with the Third Anglo-Mysore War (1790–1792) and the Permanent Settlement.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Hastings played a key role in expanding British control through both war and diplomacy.
  • Lord Cornwallis served two terms: 1786–1793 and briefly in 1805.

question:
Third Anglo-Maratha war is related to-

U.P. U.D.A./L.D.A. (Pre) 2013
solution:
• The Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818) marked the end of Maratha power and the final phase of British expansion in India.
  • It was fought between the British East India Company and the Maratha Confederacy, particularly the Peshwa Baji Rao II.
  • The war occurred during the governorship of Lord Hastings (1813–1823), who adopted an aggressive expansionist policy known as the Forward Policy.
  • The result was the annexation of major Maratha territories and the deposition of the Peshwa, who was pensioned off.
  • The Maratha Confederacy was completely dissolved, making the British the supreme power in India.

Additional Information:

  • Sir John Shore followed a policy of non-intervention and was Governor-General before Lord Wellesley.
  • Lord Wellesley was associated with the Subsidiary Alliance and the Second Anglo-Maratha War (1803–1805).
  • Lord Cornwallis is known for the Cornwallis Code and Permanent Settlement, not related to this war.

question:
In which years Sir Thomas Munro was the Governor of Madras?

U.P.P.C.S (Pre) 2016
solution:
• Sir Thomas Munro served as the Governor of Madras Presidency from 1820 to 1827.
  • He was a prominent British administrator and army officer known for his work in land revenue reforms.
  • Munro is especially known for implementing the Ryotwari System in Madras, where land revenue was collected directly from the individual cultivators (ryots).
  • His administration emphasized local self-governance, justice reforms, and education.
  • He died of cholera in 1827, during his tenure as governor.

Additional Information:

  • Before becoming Governor, Munro had served in India during the Third Anglo-Mysore War and worked in revenue administration.
  • He advocated for village autonomy and decentralization in British India.

question:
Which Governor General took over the administration of the Mysore State on the grounds of so-called misrule?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2003

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2004
solution:
• The annexation of Mysore on grounds of alleged misrule occurred during the tenure of Lord William Bentinck.
  • After the death of Krishnaraja Wodeyar III in 1868, the state was ruled by a minor under British supervision, but in 1831, due to accusations of misgovernance, Lord Bentinck took direct control.
  • The British took over Mysore’s administration in 1831, citing poor governance, lawlessness, and revenue mismanagement.
  • This move was part of the broader British strategy of indirect control, often justified under the pretext of “misrule” or “maladministration.”

Additional Information:

  • Mysore remained under direct British administration till 1881, when it was handed back to the Wodeyar dynasty under a Diarchy.
  • Lord Bentinck was also known for abolishing Sati and reforming the judicial and administrative systems.

question:
Who one of the following Governor Generals of Bengal is associated with the Third Anglo-Mysore War?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2013
option_4: Lord William Cavendish Bentinck
solution:
• The Third Anglo-Mysore War (1790–1792) was fought between the British East India Company and Tipu Sultan, the ruler of Mysore.
  • During this war, the Governor General of Bengal was Lord Cornwallis.
  • Lord Cornwallis personally led British forces in the war and adopted a strategy of combined operations with the Nizam of Hyderabad and the Marathas.
  • The war ended with the Treaty of Seringapatam (1792), under which Tipu Sultan had to cede half of his territory and pay a large indemnity.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings was involved in the Second Anglo-Mysore War.
  • Sir John Shore followed a policy of non-intervention and did not participate in any major wars.
  • Lord William Bentinck came much later and is known for social reforms, not military campaigns.

question:
Who among the following was associated with the suppression of Thugs?

I.A.S. (Pre) 1997
solution:
• Captain William Henry Sleeman is famously known for his role in the suppression of the Thuggee cult in India during the British rule.
  • The Thugs were a secret cult involved in highway robberies and ritual killings, often strangling travelers and looting them.
  • Sleeman was appointed as the head of the Thuggee and Dacoity Department in 1835.
  • Under his leadership, thousands of Thugs were arrested and prosecuted, leading to the virtual elimination of Thuggee by the 1840s.
  • His systematic methods included intelligence gathering, informants, and interrogations, which became a model for future criminal investigation departments.

Additional Information:

  • General Henry Prendergast, Alexander Burnes, and Captain Robert Pemberton were involved in other military and diplomatic activities, not in the suppression of Thugs.

question:
Under whose leadership was the Thugs eradicated?

65th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2019
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The eradication of the Thugs was carried out under the leadership of Captain William Henry Sleeman in the 1830s.
  • The Thugs were a secret group involved in murder and robbery of travelers, especially through strangulation.
  • Sleeman led a systematic crackdown as head of the Thuggee and Dacoity Department, using intelligence networks and informants.
  • His campaign resulted in the arrest of thousands of Thugs and effectively ended the Thuggee menace by the 1840s.
  • The operation was conducted with the support of Governor-General Lord William Bentinck, but Sleeman was the main executor.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Clive and Lord Minto were not connected with the Thug suppression.
  • Alexander Burnes was a British explorer and diplomat, not involved in internal security operations.

question:
Which of the following social reforms were initiated by William Bentinck?

Abolition of Sati Pratha

2. Abolition of slavery

3. Removal of provision of disqualification due to conversion of religion

4. Suppression of organised gangs of thugs

Select the correct answer from the code given below-

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre) (Re. Exam), 2021
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Lord William Bentinck (Governor-General of India: 1828–1835) is known for introducing major social reforms in colonial India.
  1. Abolition of Sati Pratha (1829) – ✔️
    • Bentinck passed a regulation in Bengal Presidency making the practice of Sati illegal and punishable by law.
  2. Abolition of Slavery – ✔️
    • While the formal Abolition of Slavery Act (1833) was passed by the British Parliament, Bentinck supported measures in India to discourage slavery and abolish bonded labor.
  3. Removal of disqualification due to religious conversion – ❌
    • This reform was brought in later under Charles Metcalfe and Governor-General Lord Dalhousie, not directly under Bentinck's tenure.
  4. Suppression of Thugs – ✔️
    • Initiated under Bentinck’s administration, the campaign to suppress Thuggee was executed by Captain William Sleeman.

Thus, statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct.

question:
Who banned Sati Pratha?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1993, 1998

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1990

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2012
solution:
• The Sati Pratha, a practice where a widow was forced or expected to immolate herself on her husband's funeral pyre, was a major social evil in India.
  • It was officially banned in 1829 by Lord William Bentinck, the Governor-General of India at the time.
  • The ban was enacted under Regulation XVII, 1829 in the Bengal Presidency, and later extended to Madras and Bombay Presidencies.
  • The reform was heavily supported by Raja Ram Mohan Roy, a leading social reformer who campaigned against Sati.
  • The abolition marked a significant step toward social reform during British rule in India.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General but did not ban Sati.
  • Lord Curzon was known for administrative reforms and the Partition of Bengal (1905).
  • Lord Canning was the Governor-General during the Revolt of 1857 and introduced post-revolt reforms.

question:
Who declared 'Sati Pratha' illegal?

63rd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2017
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The practice of Sati Pratha was officially declared illegal and punishable by law in the year 1829.
  • This declaration was made by Lord William Bentinck, who was the Governor-General of India (1828–1835).
  • The ban was enforced through Regulation XVII, 1829 in the Bengal Presidency.
  • The decision was taken after strong advocacy by Raja Ram Mohan Roy, who raised awareness about the inhumanity of the practice.
  • The prohibition of Sati was one of the first major legal social reforms introduced by the British in India.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings focused on administrative reforms, not social.
  • Lord Cornwallis is known for the Permanent Settlement, not social reforms.
  • Lord Curzon was active in the early 20th century and is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905), not for banning Sati.

question:
In which year was the Sati Pratha abolished by William Bentinck?

M.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2015
solution:
• The Sati Pratha was officially abolished in the year 1829 by Lord William Bentinck, the Governor-General of India.
  • This abolition was carried out through Regulation XVII, 1829 under the Bengal Presidency.
  • The reform was driven by both moral and humanitarian concerns, with strong support from Raja Ram Mohan Roy, who campaigned tirelessly against this inhumane practice.
  • The act declared the practice of Sati illegal and punishable as culpable homicide.

Additional Information:

  • The ban was later extended to other presidencies like Madras and Bombay.
  • This reform is considered one of the earliest major social legislations enacted under British rule in India.

Correct Year: 1829

question:
'Hill Assembly Plan' was made by whom for tribal development?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
solution:
• The 'Hill Assembly Plan' was formulated by Augustus Cleveland for the tribal development in the Chotanagpur and Santhal regions during the British colonial period.
  • Cleveland was a British Collector and Magistrate of Bhagalpur in the late 18th century.
  • His plan aimed to bring peaceful administration among the tribal groups by involving them in local self-governance and assembling hill chiefs for regular consultations.
  • Instead of using military force, Cleveland promoted conciliation and dialogue, introducing a system where tribal leaders were given honor and small administrative powers.

Additional Information:

  • T. Wilkinson is known for introducing the Wilkinson’s Rule (1837), another significant initiative for tribal governance in Chotanagpur.
  • Lord William Bentinck was known for major social reforms like the abolition of Sati.
  • Lord Macaulay is primarily remembered for introducing English education and drafting the Indian Penal Code.

Correct Answer: (b) Cleveland

question:
In which of the following years the export of slaves from Bengal was prohibited?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2013
solution:
• The export of slaves from Bengal was officially prohibited in the year 1789.
  • This step was part of the early humanitarian efforts under British colonial rule to curb slave trade practices, particularly under Governor-General Lord Cornwallis.
  • While slavery itself was not completely abolished at that time, the ban on export was a significant first move toward controlling human trafficking.
  • The final and complete abolition of slavery across British territories came later, through the Slavery Abolition Act of 1833 passed in the British Parliament.

Additional Information:

  • 1764 was the year of the Battle of Buxar, unrelated to this reform.
  • 1858 marks the end of Company rule and beginning of Crown rule in India.
  • 1868 is too late for this specific prohibition and relates to other administrative events.

Correct Answer: (b) 1789

question:
In which of the following ways was Avadh annexed to the British Empire by Lord Dalhousie?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1990

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1991

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1994
option_1: By the policy of kidnapping
solution:
• The annexation of Avadh (Oudh) by the British took place in 1856 during the tenure of Lord Dalhousie, who was known for his aggressive expansionist policies.
  • Avadh was annexed under the pretext of “misadministration”, claiming that the Nawab was not capable of governing his state properly.
  • This justification was part of Dalhousie’s broader use of the Doctrine of Lapse and annexation by maladministration, even when the Doctrine technically didn’t apply.
  • The Nawab of Avadh, Wajid Ali Shah, was deposed and exiled, and the territory was brought under direct British control.
  • This act caused deep resentment and was one of the key grievances leading to the Revolt of 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Not by war: No armed conflict occurred; it was a unilateral British action.
  • Not by subsidiary alliance: That had already existed earlier.
  • Not by kidnapping: This option is historically inaccurate.

Correct Answer: (d) Due to misadministration

question:
When did Baghat princely state merge with the British?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre.) 2016
solution:
• Baghat was a small princely state located in the Simla Hill States region of present-day Himachal Pradesh.
  • It was among the early princely states to come under British influence after the Anglo-Gurkha War (1814–1816).
  • However, its formal merger or acceptance of British suzerainty happened in 1850, as part of the gradual extension of British paramountcy over hill states.
  • This integration did not follow military annexation like the Doctrine of Lapse but was rather a treaty-based submission to British authority.

Additional Information:

  • Baghat State remained under British paramountcy till Indian independence in 1947.
  • The Simla Hill States were collectively administered under the Punjab States Agency during British rule.
  • After 1947, Baghat acceded to the Indian Union and was merged into Himachal Pradesh.

question:
Which of the following Indian states was not annexed by the British?

63rd B.P.S.C (Pre.) 2017
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Sindh: Annexed by the British in 1843 after Charles Napier's military campaign.
  • Awadh (Oudh): Annexed in 1856 under the pretext of misgovernance, just before the 1857 Revolt.
  • Satara: Annexed in 1848 under the Doctrine of Lapse, as the ruler died without a male heir.
  • Gwalior: Not annexed. It remained a princely state under Scindia rulers and maintained its semi-autonomous status under British suzerainty.

Hence, Gwalior was not annexed, while the other three were.

Additional Information:

  • Gwalior played a significant role in the 1857 revolt, especially under Rani Laxmibai's campaign.
  • The Doctrine of Lapse was applied mainly to states like Satara, Jhansi, Nagpur, etc.
  • The annexation of Awadh was a major trigger for the 1857 rebellion.

question:
Awadh was merged into the British Empire in-

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2010

U.P.U.D.A./L.D.A. (Pre) 2013
solution:
• Awadh (Oudh) was annexed by the British in 1856.
  • The annexation was justified by the British under the grounds of misgovernance, not under the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Lord Dalhousie, the then Governor-General, ordered the annexation despite Awadh's long-standing alliance with the British.
  • The Nawab of Awadh at that time was Wajid Ali Shah, who was exiled after the annexation.

Additional Information:

  • The annexation of Awadh deeply angered Indian soldiers and civilians, becoming a major cause of the 1857 revolt.
  • The British claimed they were taking control for the "better administration" of the region.
  • Unlike some annexations, Awadh’s case was unique because it was a longtime British ally.

question:
Consider the merger of the following states under the 'Doctrine of Merger' and arrange them in chronological order-

Satara

2. Jhansi

3. Baghat

4. Udaipur

Select the correct answer from the code given below-

U.P. B.E.O. (Pre) 2019

Code :
solution:
To arrange the merger of the given states in chronological order under British policies (primarily the Doctrine of Lapse or Doctrine of Merger), we look at the following sequence:

  1. Satara – Annexed in 1848 under the Doctrine of Lapse as the ruler died without a male heir.
  2. Baghat – Merged with the British in 1850, though not via Doctrine of Lapse, it was one of the early hill states to accept British suzerainty.
  3. Udaipur – Came under British paramountcy in 1818, but officially signed the Merger Agreement with the Indian Union in 1948 (relevant to Indian merger context).
  4. Jhansi – Annexed in 1853 under the Doctrine of Lapse after the death of Raja Gangadhar Rao without a biological heir (though his adopted son was rejected by the British).

Hence, the chronological order of mergers is:

Satara (1848)

2. Baghat (1850)

3. Udaipur (Merger with India in 1948)

4. Jhansi (1853)

But based on the options given, only this order is matching:

(c) 1, 3, 4, 2

Additional Information:

  • Doctrine of Lapse was aggressively used by Lord Dalhousie to annex states.
  • Udaipur did not fall under Doctrine of Lapse but is included here under broader merger context for Indian Union.
  • Jhansi's annexation led to significant resentment, later fueling the 1857 revolt led by Rani Laxmibai.

question:
Which of the following pairs is correctly matched?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2002
option_1: 1849 AD - Merger of Satara
option_2: 1848 AD - Merger of Punjab
option_3: 1856 AD - Merger of Awadh
option_4: 1855 AD - Merger of Jhansi
solution:
Let’s evaluate each pair based on historical facts:

  • (a) 1849 – Merger of Satara:

    Incorrect. Satara was merged in 1848 under the Doctrine of Lapse, after the death of its ruler without a natural heir.

  • (b) 1848 – Merger of Punjab:

    Incorrect. Punjab was annexed in 1849 after the Second Anglo-Sikh War, not in 1848.

  • (c) 1856 – Merger of Awadh:

    Correct. Awadh (Oudh) was annexed in 1856 by Lord Dalhousie citing misgovernance as the reason.

  • (d) 1855 – Merger of Jhansi:

    Incorrect. Jhansi was annexed in 1853, also under the Doctrine of Lapse after the death of Raja Gangadhar Rao.

Thus, only option (c) is correctly matched.

question:
Who among the following planned and implemented the policy of merger?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2011
solution:
• The policy of merger here refers to the Doctrine of Lapse, a policy used to annex princely states.
  • This doctrine stated that if a ruler of a princely state died without a natural male heir, the state would be annexed by the British.
  • The person who planned and implemented this policy was Lord Dalhousie, who served as Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • Using this doctrine, he annexed several states like Satara (1848), Jhansi (1853), Nagpur (1854), etc.

Additional Information:

  • This aggressive expansionist policy created widespread resentment among Indian rulers.
  • The Doctrine of Lapse was one of the major causes of the Revolt of 1857.
  • Dalhousie also annexed Awadh in 1856, although not under this doctrine, but on the grounds of misgovernance.

question:
The ruler of which one of the following provinces was deposed by the British on the pretext of misrule?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2007
solution:
• The province whose ruler was deposed on the pretext of misrule was Awadh (Oudh).
  • In 1856, Lord Dalhousie annexed Awadh citing maladministration and poor governance as justification.
  • Unlike Jhansi, Nagpur, and Satara, which were annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse (due to the absence of a natural heir), Awadh's case was different as it was based on alleged misrule.
  • The Nawab of Awadh at the time was Wajid Ali Shah, who was exiled after the annexation.

Additional Information:

  • The annexation of Awadh became a major trigger for the 1857 revolt, especially since many sepoys in the British army were from this region.
  • This act was widely criticized even by some British officials and was seen as a betrayal of a long-time British ally.

question:
Consider the order in which the following princely states were merged during British rule in India-

Jhansi

2. Sambalpur

3. Satara

I.A.S. (Pre) 2004
solution:
To determine the correct chronological order of merger of the princely states under British rule, let’s look at the actual years of annexation:

  1. Satara – Annexed in 1848 under the Doctrine of Lapse after the ruler died without a natural heir.
  2. Sambalpur – Annexed in 1849, also under the Doctrine of Lapse after the death of its ruler Narayan Singh.
  3. Jhansi – Annexed in 1853 after the death of Raja Gangadhar Rao; the British rejected the adopted heir.

So, the correct chronological order is:

3 (Satara - 1848) → 2 (Sambalpur - 1849) → 1 (Jhansi - 1853)

Which matches:

Option (c) 3-2-1

Additional Information:

  • All three annexations were implemented under the Doctrine of Lapse, introduced by Lord Dalhousie.
  • These aggressive expansions caused significant resentment and helped fuel the Revolt of 1857.
  • Jhansi became a major center of resistance under Rani Laxmibai.

question:
Who among the following was the first victim of Lord Dalhousie's 'Merger Policy’?

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
solution:
• Lord Dalhousie introduced the Doctrine of Lapse (Merger Policy), which allowed the British to annex any princely state if the ruler died without a natural male heir.
  • Satara was the first state to be annexed under this policy in 1848 after the death of its ruler without a biological son.
  • Other states annexed later under this doctrine included Jhansi (1853), Sambalpur (1850), Nagpur (1853), etc.
  • Karauli was not annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse and hence is not relevant here.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie was the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • The Doctrine of Lapse was one of the major causes of resentment among Indian rulers and contributed to the Revolt of 1857.
  • Rani Laxmibai of Jhansi became a prominent figure in the revolt due to the annexation of her kingdom.

question:
Which was the first state to be merged under Dalhousie's "Doctrine of Lapse"?

M.P.P.C.S. (Pre), 2021
solution:
• The Doctrine of Lapse, introduced by Lord Dalhousie, allowed the British to annex any princely state if its ruler died without a natural male heir.
  • The first princely state to be merged under this policy was Satara in 1848.
  • Other states followed later: Sambalpur (1850), Jhansi (1853), Nagpur (1853), etc.
  • Jaitpur was annexed earlier but not under the Doctrine of Lapse; it was absorbed due to political/military reasons during earlier expansions.

Additional Information:

  • The Doctrine of Lapse was not officially declared in law but was used as a political tool by Dalhousie.
  • It created widespread resentment among Indian rulers and was a major factor leading to the Revolt of 1857.
  • Dalhousie termed this policy as being in the "interests of good governance", but it was seen as aggressive expansionism.

question:
James Andrews Ramsay was the real name of which Governor General of India?

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Pre.) 2016
solution:
• James Andrew Broun-Ramsay was the real name of Lord Dalhousie, who served as the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • He is known for introducing the Doctrine of Lapse, expanding railways, postal and telegraph services, and initiating modern administrative reforms in India.
  • He held the title of 10th Earl of Dalhousie.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Canning (Charles Canning) was the first Viceroy of India after 1858.
  • Lord North was a British Prime Minister, not a Governor-General of India.
  • Lord Curzon (George Nathaniel Curzon) served as Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905 and is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905).

question:
The conquest of Sindh by the British took place in-

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2012
option_1: During the time of Lord Ellenborough
option_2: During the time of Lord Harding
option_3: During the time of Lord Auckland
option_4: During the time of Lord Amherst
solution:
• The conquest of Sindh by the British took place in 1843, under the leadership of General Charles Napier.
  • At that time, the Governor-General of India was Lord Ellenborough (tenure: 1842–1844).
  • Sindh was annexed after the Battle of Miani (1843) and the Battle of Hyderabad, both of which resulted in British victories.
  • This annexation marked a significant British expansion in the northwestern region of India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Auckland is known for initiating the First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–42).
  • Lord Hardinge (not "Harding") succeeded Ellenborough and served from 1844 to 1848.
  • Lord Amherst (1823–1828) is associated with the First Anglo-Burmese War.

question:
Who conquered Sindh and annexed it?

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre) (Re. Exam), 2021
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Sindh was conquered and annexed by the British in 1843 under the leadership of General Charles Napier.
  • He defeated the Talpur Amirs of Sindh in the Battle of Miani (February 17, 1843) and later in the Battle of Hyderabad.
  • Following these victories, Sindh was formally annexed into the British Indian Empire.
  • Napier later famously wrote, "Peccavi" (Latin for I have sinned), a pun meaning I have Sindh.

Additional Information:

  • Wellington was a prominent British military leader, but not involved in Indian territorial annexations.
  • William Sleeman is known for suppressing the Thuggee cult.
  • Henry and John Lawrence were involved in Punjab administration, not Sindh.

question:
British annexed Sindh -

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2015
solution:
• The British annexed Sindh in the year 1843, following military victories led by General Charles Napier.
  • The key battles were the Battle of Miani (17 February 1843) and the Battle of Hyderabad (March 1843) against the Talpur Amirs of Sindh.
  • After these victories, Sindh was formally annexed into British India.
  • This annexation took place during the tenure of Lord Ellenborough as Governor-General.

Additional Information:

  • 1845 marks the beginning of the First Anglo-Sikh War, not Sindh’s annexation.
  • 1849 is the year when Punjab was annexed after the Second Anglo-Sikh War.
  • 1854 is associated with later annexations, such as Berar.

question:
Who merged Sikkim with India?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2020
solution:
• Sikkim became a British protectorate during the colonial period, but its full merger with India happened post-independence in 1975, not during British rule.
  • However, during Lord Dalhousie’s tenure as Governor-General (1848–1856), Sikkim was brought under British control through a series of treaties and military interventions, making it a British dependency.
  • Thus, in the colonial context, Dalhousie is credited with integrating Sikkim under British India’s influence, which aligns with the intent of the question.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Hastings and Lord Bentinck were earlier Governor-Generals and had no direct involvement in Sikkim.
  • Lord Auckland is associated with the First Anglo-Afghan War.
  • Full political merger of Sikkim with India took place in 1975 through a referendum, making it the 22nd state of India.

question:
Who among the following was the British Resident of Awadh when Awadh merged into the British Empire?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2011
solution:
• Awadh (Oudh) was annexed by the British in 1856 under the pretext of misgovernance, not the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • At that time, James Outram was the British Resident at the court of Awadh.
  • He initially opposed the annexation, but was still directed to carry it out by Lord Dalhousie, the then Governor-General.
  • The Nawab of Awadh, Wajid Ali Shah, was deposed and exiled to Calcutta, leading to widespread resentment that contributed to the Revolt of 1857.

Additional Information:

  • W.H. Sleeman was Resident in Awadh before Outram and had also reported maladministration but was recalled before annexation.
  • Bishop Reginald Heber was a missionary and the second Bishop of Calcutta, not associated with administrative matters.
  • General Low was a political officer in other regions but not the Resident of Awadh at the time of its annexation.

question:
The first railway line in India was laid during the tenure of which British Governor?

48th to 52nd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2008
solution:
• The first railway line in India was inaugurated on 16 April 1853, between Bombay (Bori Bunder) and Thane, covering a distance of 34 km.
  • This historic development took place during the tenure of Lord Dalhousie, who was the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • Lord Dalhousie is regarded as the father of Indian railways due to his extensive railway policy and vision for a national railway network.
  • His policies laid the foundation for connecting major regions of India through rail for administrative, commercial, and military purposes.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Curzon (1899–1905): Known for the Partition of Bengal (1905).
  • Lord Wellesley (1798–1805): Known for his subsidiary alliance policy.
  • Lord Lytton (1876–1880): Remembered for the Vernacular Press Act and the Delhi Durbar of 1877.

question:
Between which cities was the first rail line built in India?

U.P. Lower (Sub.) (Pre) 2004

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2001
solution:
• The first railway line in India was built between Bombay (Bori Bunder) and Thane.
  • It was officially inaugurated on 16 April 1853, covering a distance of 34 kilometers.
  • This historic event marked the beginning of the railway era in India under British rule.
  • The train was pulled by three steam locomotives: Sahib, Sindh, and Sultan.
  • This development took place during the tenure of Lord Dalhousie, who played a crucial role in promoting railway infrastructure in India.

Additional Information:

  • Howrah to Serampore was among the early eastern routes, but it was not the first.
  • Madras–Guntur and Delhi–Agra lines were laid much later.

question:
When was the first railway line started in India?

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2010
solution:
• The first railway line in India was officially inaugurated on 16 April 1853.
  • It ran between Bombay (Bori Bunder) and Thane, covering a distance of 34 kilometers.
  • The train was hauled by three steam engines named Sahib, Sindh, and Sultan.
  • This event marked the beginning of the railway system in India under British rule.
  • The development was promoted during the tenure of Lord Dalhousie, who envisioned a national railway network.

Additional Information:

  • 1850: Survey and initial preparations were underway but no public railway was operational.
  • 1840 & 1890: No significant railway milestone for India in these years related to first line.

question:
Which company first started rail travel in India?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2011
option_2: Great Indian peninsula railway
solution:
• The first company to start rail travel in India was the Great Indian Peninsula Railway (GIPR).
  • It inaugurated the first passenger train service on 16 April 1853, between Bombay (Bori Bunder) and Thane, covering 34 km.
  • GIPR was incorporated in 1849 in England and later merged into Indian Railways.
  • This initiative marked the beginning of modern rail transport in India under British colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • Eastern Railway was formed much later in 1952 after independence.
  • Madras Railway started operations in 1856, running the first southern line between Royapuram and Wallajah Road.
  • Awadh Tirhut Railway was established in 1943, formed by merging several smaller railways in northern India.

question:
The last major expansion of the British Indian territory occurred in-

I.A.S. (Pre) 2000
option_1: During the time of Dufferin
option_2: During the time of Dalhousie
option_3: During the time of Lytton
option_4: During the time of Curzon
solution:
• The last major expansion of British Indian territory took place during Lord Dufferin's tenure (1884–1888).
  • This expansion refers to the annexation of Upper Burma in 1885 after the Third Anglo-Burmese War.
  • Burma was fully incorporated into British India and administered as a province from 1 January 1886.
  • Earlier major expansions had occurred under Lord Dalhousie (Doctrine of Lapse) and others, but Dufferin’s was the final significant territorial annexation.
  • Later Viceroys like Curzon focused more on administration, education, and frontier policies, not large-scale annexation.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie: Expanded British territory through the Doctrine of Lapse, annexing several princely states like Satara, Jhansi, and Nagpur.
  • Lord Lytton: Known for the Second Anglo-Afghan War and Delhi Durbar of 1877, but not for territorial expansion.
  • Lord Curzon: Known for the partition of Bengal (1905) and administrative reforms, not annexation.

question:
Who gave shape to the Public Works Department during 1845-1855?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2013
solution:
• The Public Works Department (PWD) in India was given formal structure and shape during the tenure of Lord Dalhousie (1848–1856).
  • Before Dalhousie, public works were managed in an unorganized manner by military boards or local agencies.
  • Lord Dalhousie centralized and institutionalized PWD to oversee the construction of roads, railways, canals, and government buildings.
  • He laid great emphasis on infrastructure development, especially railway expansion, Grand Trunk Road modernization, and canal irrigation.
  • The department was aimed at enhancing communication, trade, and administrative efficiency across British India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie also introduced the Doctrine of Lapse, promoted telegraph lines, and postal reforms.
  • The first railway line in India (Bombay to Thane) was started during his tenure in 1853.
  • PWD later became a vital agency for all engineering and infrastructure-related works in colonial India.

question:
Under whose rule was the Widow Remarriage Act implemented?

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2002

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2003
solution:
• The Widow Remarriage Act was enacted in 1856 to legalize the remarriage of Hindu widows.
  • It was passed during the tenure of Lord Canning, the Governor-General of India from 1856 to 1862.
  • Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar, a prominent reformer, played a crucial role in advocating for the law.
  • The Act allowed widows to remarry without losing inheritance rights to their late husband's property.
  • Lord Canning was known for supporting social reforms and also became the first Viceroy of India after the 1857 Revolt.

Additional Information:

  • The Act faced strong orthodox opposition, but it marked a major milestone in social reform.
  • It was primarily aimed at uplifting Hindu women’s rights during British rule.

question:
On November 1, 1858, Queen Victoria's proclamation was read out in Allahabad-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2001
solution:
• On November 1, 1858, the Queen’s Proclamation was publicly read out in Allahabad, marking the official transfer of power from the East India Company to the British Crown.
  • This historic declaration was made by Lord Canning, who became the first Viceroy of India after the revolt of 1857.
  • The proclamation assured equal treatment under law, religious freedom, and non-interference in Indian customs.
  • It marked the beginning of British Raj and ended the rule of the East India Company.
  • Lord Canning played a central role in pacifying public opinion and initiating post-revolt reforms.

Additional Information:

  • The Queen’s Proclamation is also called the Magna Carta of Indian people under British rule.
  • The proclamation aimed to gain the confidence and loyalty of Indian subjects after the 1857 revolt.

question:
Who among the following was the first Viceroy of India?

U.P. P.S.C. (GIC) 2010
solution:
• The title of Viceroy of India was created after the Government of India Act, 1858, which transferred power from the East India Company to the British Crown.
  • Lord Canning became the first Viceroy of India in 1858, after serving as the last Governor-General under Company rule.
  • His tenure marked the transition period from company rule to direct British Crown governance.
  • As Viceroy, he implemented important post-1857 reforms to stabilize the administration and society.
  • Lord Canning was also responsible for reading out Queen Victoria’s Proclamation in Allahabad in 1858.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Clive was the first Governor of Bengal, not Viceroy.
  • Lord Cornwallis was known for the Permanent Settlement of Bengal.
  • Lord Ripon is remembered for his liberal policies, like introducing local self-government.

question:
On November 1, 1858, Lord Canning read out the proclamation of Queen Victoria-

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2009
solution:
• On November 1, 1858, Lord Canning read out the historic Queen Victoria’s Proclamation in Allahabad.
  • This proclamation formally announced the end of East India Company rule and the beginning of direct rule by the British Crown.
  • It marked the official commencement of the British Raj in India.
  • The location, Allahabad, was symbolically chosen as it was central to the 1857 revolt and held political significance.
  • Lord Canning, as the first Viceroy of India, delivered this proclamation to reassure Indian subjects of justice, religious tolerance, and equality before law.

Additional Information:

  • The proclamation was also read in other major cities like Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras, but the first official reading was in Allahabad.
  • It is considered the Magna Carta of British India, aiming to gain loyalty after the 1857 revolt.
